content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												I can't complain since I bought this for 19 cents.  That's basically me selling two steam trading cards.The feeling the game gives off... I don't how many of you remember "The Very Hungry Caterpillar," but it invokes that same kind of nostalgic blast of color, something that mesmerizes you.  It is more than ten times as bright and vivid as that book, but as adults that's what it takes to overload your senses.  At the same time there is an ever-present sensation of faded-ness.  Like the bright colors are constantly waning and all your efforts is only leading you to the end of both the game and your buggy life.The game play is nothing special.  It is just a point and click with a few puzzles.Note:  Screw the beetle lock!  That took me half an hour.  That's 25% of the time spent on this game wasted on a bland rock with five bugs on it!

Posted: July 12, 2015
												Not really worth the full price. Get it cheap, it might be worth your time, but that is a very short time. A good portion of the time I spent in this game, I was distracted texting my girlfriend. It's kinda like a really pretty game of I Spy, but it's really over very quickly, and some of the features aren't very intuitive. For instance, to solve one puzzle you have to collect several of what I assume to be little pebbles of food. To find them,  you have to move your insect to little pods on the branch, and click on your insect to make the green particle thing happen. Either that, or you click (and drag, maybe) on the pods to open them.  Here's the thing that really disappointed me at the end of the game: I found out there was card drops. I have no motivation to play the game to actually collect them! I got one, but I don't even want to play the game again to get the other two, because it's done, there's no more adventure, and I'm just not interested. If you get the game on sale and cheap, fine, play it, enjoy the visuals and music, it's nice. However, other than that it's just not worth it.

Posted: August 10, 2015
												This is one of those "Is this a game?" kind of adventures. But who cares anymore? It's a beautiful piece of art, there are some things to consider before buying it for the full price:Pros:* Absolutely beautiful to see* Some nice and not too hard find-the-objects action* Original and clever little puzzlesCons:* Didn't have any sound for me, for some reason* Some puzzles are way too hard, I found myself clicking randomly in two of them* It can ve reaaaaally slow to go from A to B* Even with all the puzzles and walking around it is very short, took me 1.6 hours to complete (Please don't refund it, guys)* Achievements are meaningless, you get them just by progressing and there's 100% possibility in having all of them just by finishing the game* No replay valueAll in all, I liked it. Posted: October 29, 2015
												For £0.15 this game was worth it, but by god the last puzzle with the bugs you have to slide around made me want to stick pins in my own eyes. Whether it sounds salty or not - it ruined the game for me.You have this beautiful landscape to look at, and sure, the bug moves along at the slowest pace imaginable - I can deal with that, I just look at the pretties and whatever, but the last puzzle? Good god, seriously, if you removed the last puzzle or changed it or something, I'd pay more, I really would.The other puzzles throughout the game are great, they get a bit difficult at times and I know from the game forums that people who are colour blind struggle with some parts, so to have such a road block right at the end of an otherwise peaceful, chilled game just♥♥♥♥♥♥all over it for me personally.The music is lovely, the game looks wonderful. Your little bug dude moves at a snail's pace and while the game has hidden object elements it's relatively straightforward. Get ready to back track quite a lot however as these objects are strewn across several screens. I personally wouldn't have minded less game time in return for less back tracking, it feels like you're being forced to just play for longer sometimes and that's never enjoyable in a game that is already pretty short. I would say the achievements are easy to get but I still just can't get past the last puzzle so I can't 100% :(Also, the game doesn't feature a proper save system, so if you get mid way through a scene, DON'T quit, because you'll be forced to start the entire level again from the beginning (again, wouldn't be as much of a ball ache if the bug didn't move so slow). At present I can't bring myself to stare at that last puzzle for the 15 minutes I've already sank into the activity, but I recommend the game based on its otherwise pleasant presentation.(....but really I want to be a petty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and click 'no' purely because of that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ bug puzzle...can you taste the salt?)

Posted: December 29, 2015
												This game is odd, but in a good way.I can't tell what it's trying to be; whether it's a child's game, with dark, underlying themes, or whether it's an adventure into a mystical world just below normal human perception. But whatever it is, it's incredible. The puzzles were mostly easy (with the exception of the trickier final puzzle) and the gameplay was point and click, which searching aspects. But this, for me, was less of a game, and more of an experience. The art was absolutely awesome, and gave the world a unique and intriguing twist I haven't seen in a story game before.Should you buy it? That depends. If you're the kind of person who sits down for five minutes, leaves, and comes back, don't buy this. But if you like to take your time, and involve yourself in a game, this story without words would appeal to you like no other.The soundtrack made me just sit down and listen to the music, while the screen displayed just a menu, for about five minutes before starting the game. Each environment gave me a new sense of accomplishment, and I just look back on it and smile. That is, until I play it again.It is a short game, but it will change you.

Posted: April 12, 2016
												Morphopolis is a very artsy game.  Beautiful and colorful and a little surreal.At it's core it's a hidden object puzzle game where you find objects and then use them on other objects. Sometimes this initiates a puzzle that you have to complete.  Some objects in the environment you need to click on to initiate the ability to go on an object hunt which was a little annoying, though not unfair. Just remember if it looks important click on it once to see if it pops up that it wants something.The game barely has any instructions and mostly you're just on your own.  But despite the lack of any prompts that tell you what to do the game doesn't just leave you hanging as the puzzles do make enough sense that one should be able to piece together what you need to do. I only have problems with one puzzle that I needed to look up how to do it.Morphopolis feels like it was designed to play on a tablet, phone, or any sort of touch screen as the controls are 'click & hold' or 'click & drag' oriented. Though this did not really subtract from the game for me.The game is short (I beat it in about 2 hours) and does not really have any replay value but I still say buy it if you got a couple of extra dollars available. It's a nice little game to waste some time on and it's dang pretty to look at.P.S. You'll 100% the game on your first play-though probably.

Posted: April 4, 2016
												I have to admit: I have not finished this game. I had to give up when I encountered the last puzzle. Was too hard to overcome for me. But will I come back sometime to finish what I started? Indeed I think so.Morphopolis is very simple game. You only need to click at certain objects in order to move "story" forward. It uses oldschool mechanics from simillar games, so it is not innovative at any point. I have a feeling that it is specially designed to be longer than it had to be. You will often find yourself wandering around the same locations just to pick a mushroom that you couldn't pick last time you were there. Also game is very short in it's core "story".But Morphopolis is beautiful. Really. And has so relaxing and nice music. It is great way to spend 2/3 hours. Not more though, unless you won't be bored doing the same thing over and over again.I can easily recommend this game and give it 7/10.Pro:- price- graphics- music- conceptCon:- too short- takes too much space- is designed to be longer than it should be

												it's a game mainly about patience & miniscule observation. very pretty done, relaxing & somewhat disturbingly eerie too.the music alone is already stunningly hypnotic, i like it very much & instead of the art i would prefer the soundtrack as an additional content, but that's just me. it reminds me of some pieces by Future 3.the only negative thing i have to say about Morphopolis is that it's very short, 5 chapters only. it's a pity.because it's that kind of a game where you could go on & on & when stuck, then you put it aside frustrated & come back later to finish the next small piece of the path.i played months ago a game with exactly the same principle, Tiny Big Bang Story, which is fortunately much longer.in any case a game one should take time for, at least internally.i highly recommend it, only, rather at a somewhat lowered price, it's too short for the full amount of 5€.it is also available for iPad, which i will probably buy too, i think, it's just one of those rare little games one has to own & enjoy for their own sake.

Posted: October 24, 2015
												Positives:-The music is very relaxing.-The art is pretty.-Some of the puzzles are pretty fun, and you feel pretty smart for having solved them.-Nice if you like "find the hidden object"-type games.Negatives:-The controls for moving are crap.  Half the time you won't even realize you can go somewhere until you accidentally hold the mouse in the wrong area.  Other times, your bug keeps moving back and forth in the same spot as you try to find the place that'll make it go not just right, but right and downwards.  Sometimes you'll try clicking an object and end up moving your bug back over to the other screen for no apparent reason, even though you weren't clicking in that direction.-On a similar note, you are SLOW.  Slow, slow, slow, slow, SLOW.  Which wouldn't be SO bad, but since you're constantly moving back and forth between screens (using the same crummy controls) to find stuff you missed, it's just unbearable.  I feel like the game would have been at least a half an hour shorter if I could change screens faster.-So much random clicking to figure out what's important.  See, you don't actually find out what you need to collect until you click on something, like another bug, or a plant.  Sorta like they're giving you a quest.  Usually it's easy enough to figure out what needs clicking, but other times, you have no freaking idea how you're supposed to progress without taking a hint.-By level three, you'll start to recognize that the weird orange orbs are gonna need collecting before you can burrow into your next target's brain.  But no, you can't grab anything you know you're gonna need until after the 'quest' is given to you, forcing you to slowly, SLOWLY backtrack through all of the screens to grab them.  I don't mean to sound impatient, but God.  Crawl across the screen a little faster, bug.  Come on!  Hustle, hustle!-No idea where the "pathways" to the next screen are.  Have fun crawling (SLOWLY) across the screen, only to realize it's a dead end.  Then crawl (SLOWLY) back, not sure whether there's another screen, or if you're just bad at finding items.-Did I mention that you're slow?  Because you're slow.  SO FREAKING SLOW.-A couple puzzles are really annoying for the wrong reasons.  For example, the flower puzzle gives you no indication of the controls.  I spent ages clicking around and hoping something would happen, but nope!  It's actually a Chinese Checkers-style puzzle where you have to try and get all but one of the seed thingies to disappear, but without a walkthrough, I never would have figured out the rules and controls.  Figuring out what the freaking puzzle is isn't a puzzle.-No mid-level saves.  Levels aren't usually that long, but if you get stuck on something and call it quits for the night, have fun slowly, slowly, SLOWLY crawling across the screen several more times to complete the initial collection quests again.  SLOWLY.-I don't know if I just accidentally skipped it, or what (in which case it shouldn't be so easy to accidentally skip, because I'm not gonna freaking replay that last puzzle just to see it) but I went into the place I was supposed to go, and... That was it.  The game just ended.  I got an achievement, and then I was back at the menu.  Ghosts 'n' Goblins had a better ending than that!Summary:If you can get it on sale and really, REALLY like hidden object games, it might be worth it, but there are plenty of free games on the internet that aren't so, well, SLOW.  Seriously, I'm not kidding, it's really gonna get on your nerves.  Don't even think about paying the full five dollars for this.  I mean, I appreciate the effort the developers put into it, and everything, but this isn't worth two dollars and fifty cents per hour.

												This is how you elevate a game above most others in its genre.A standard point-and-click puzzle/hidden object game, except with superb visuals and an interesting world to navigate. Posted: September 24, 2015
												Morphopolis knows what it wants to do.  Provide a game that runs off the player's curiosity, and provide a few simple puzzles for the player to figure out on their own.  I love how it had no dialogue, leaving me to try and figure out what the heck I was doing for most of the time.  Though it's controls are restricted to the mouse, the game still feels like the antithesis of a lot of modern games, and feels like it pays tribute to an era lost in gaming where hand holding wasn't mandatory.ProsVery pleasing asthetic.  From what I understand, it was hand-drawn, and looked very good.  A lot of life from a soft palette, and I didn't feel like any problematic circumstances were due to the visuals.Again, I had a lot of freedom (even though the gameplay was technically on rails) to explore and tackle the puzzles as they came.  You don't see that often nowadays.ConsThe music was a bit of a wash.  My experience only lasted about an hour and a half, but most of the music is just some percussion and a xylophone - which wasn't as immersive when it hasn't noticibly changed 80% through the game.  I think there were other types of music at the start of the levels, but they inevitably sounded the same.My VerdictI think anyone who is considering buying this should understand what it was made for - a brief session of immersive puzzle solving in a visualy pleasing art style.  I personally, enjoyed my experience with it (where others clearly have not).  It's short, sweet, and - though I don't think of it as a particularly memorable experience - believe it was worth my time.7 / 10

Posted: November 11, 2015
												This is a cute game where you control various bugs which go around solving puzzles and collecting hidden objects. It looks vaguely like one of those adult colouring in books and has a calming (if somewhat repetitive) Zen-ish soundtrack to go along with it.The main problem is that the puzzles vary wildly in their difficulty. Some are really easy, like the Memory puzzle with beetles with different numbers of spots on their back or the glowworm pattern repeating puzzle. Others are harder and really difficult to do without a walkthrough, like the petal Draughts and the last Beetle Lock (never doing that again). There are also a few weird bugs (!!) here and there, like when my aphid (part 3 I think?) refused to dissolve the little red balls surrounding the squiggles I had to collect (I prefer to call them squiggles to imagining they're gross maggots or whatever). Like, he would spray his green goop and make his little sucking motion, but he just wouldn't suck up the red balls. Resetting the game entirely and redoing everything he did it fine, but that was really weird and I suspect would have put off someone who does not like wasting their time as much as I do.It would also be really nice to include colourblind options in this game. A lot of the puzzles really need it (like the beetle lock puzzle) and, besides, it's the year of our luigi 2015 - you should be including colourblind options just by default.I would tentatively recommend this game, because it's cheap and very pretty. I wouldn't recommend paying more than a dollar or two for it, though.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												I'd have to describe this as "a pretty poor game". That is to say, "it's pretty", and "it's a poor game". I picked it up dirt cheap because my never-plays-computer-games girlfriend (and I) enjoyed Machinariam and The Tiny Bang Story, the advertised equivalents, but aside from the nice art style there was no comparison. She lost interest in under ten minutes, and I only persevered because I didn't want to waste my 20 cents...It's nice-looking, searching out the grubs and beetles to collect is about as entertaining as finding the goals in any other such game, and the occasional puzzles you unlock are adequate (though few), but the pointless requirement to click-and-hold on invisible paths to compel the insect to transition between screens was surely intended to draw out a game that could otherwise be finished in half the time. Naturally, you have to page back-and-forth to trigger new requests to satisfy, but making me wait doing nothing with the mouse button pressed was an annoyance. It didn't help that on my ageing PC the game often ran like a three-legged dog with terminal asthma; I finished it in 2 hours, but it could have been 30 minutes. This is five levels of hide-and-seek that offers no reward for the ultimate completion: beat the last puzzle, it just goes back to the level-selection screen and that's it. Literally no indicator that you've finished the game, other than the absence of a Number 6 to click on. Not even a pretty picture, and given that the art is this thing's only selling point that just seems lazy. It feels like something that was made by a team who watched games being played without ever playing one themselves. Nice art is not enough, not nearly.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												This game is actually really interesting. It’s a beautiful piece of art with high details and bright colors. No, I am not talking about a painting; I’m talking about the game although the game is like a painting in a way. It has a very calming feel that helps you relax as you try to work out the puzzles and find the items in which you’re looking for. It’s a very short game, only about an hour or two depending on how good you are at puzzles and hidden object games. Behind the puzzles and artwork, we have an interesting sort of story that is abstract enough for you to take what you want from it. It is one of those games that might have a deeper meaning if you really want to look for it.They don’t really explain a story line for the game much, you are thrust straight into the game as a little larva or caterpillar wiggling around. It keeps you in that insect world as you go from a small larva to a grasshopper to a bee and so on. There aren’t any times that you actually fly or jump which is kind of strange but you walk around gathering items and the end of the stage is crawling into what looks like a carcass of the bug you will be next. I know the game is called morphopolis and is supposed to be about metamorphosis but this feels more like you taking over the dead bug instead. The game play is… at times its pretty good when you get into the puzzles but the movement of the character walking around is a little hard to deal with. Times when I am clicking to find the objects, the little character that I was playing would move and go into a different scene when I am not ready for it. That’s the problem with clicking the screen being both for finding items and moving your character. There are times when my character also had trouble finding the pathways I wanted him to go on.  I think it would have been a bit easier if they had the arrow keys to move the character as I could hit the down button or up to go on those paths. The character moves very slowly which can make that part of the game boring when you have to go back and forward to collect items. There is a lot of back tracking in this and it would have been nice to be able to have the character speed up. There is one other problem that I do have with the puzzles. The puzzles don’t tell you how to do them, you sort of just have to try different things to figure it out. There was one puzzle I got stuck on because nothing I did was actually working that I had to look up what the puzzle was supposed to be so I could play it.The artwork is so amazing. It’s very high detail and is almost like a surreal painting with how playful the colors and designs are. The problem with this though is that there are times you can’t find the path you need to go on most of the time. The paths just blend in with the background or are really hard to figure out. They luckily have it so that when you click your character, a couple green sparkles will resonate from him and travel a little way along the path though sometimes its hard to see depending on how high detailed the area is around them. On the other hand, the high detail does make finding the objects your looking for all the more rewarding as it is hard to see them. The music is so calming and a little mysterious. There is one track through the whole thing and yet I never got bored of it. It’s a piano solo that almost put me to sleep a couple of times during the long walk parts. That is all I can really say on it as its just calming.Overall, it was a nice little game to play. Is it worth the money that it is on steam right now? Maybe not. I got the game on a steam sale and It was worth the amount I paid for but I’m not sure if it’s the full $4.99 worth. My recommendation is to get it on sale because it is a good game, and it is beautiful. If you get it for the normal price, then you’re mostly paying for the artwork.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Morphopolis is a beautiful, but ultimately unpolished little gem of a game. I got it on sale for about $1. For that price, it is definitely worth it. For anything more, I might not have considered it had I known what I know about it now.First impressions were good; the hand-drawn art is gorgeous and scrolls seamlessly, and the music is okay enough, albeit a little repetitive.My frustration began in the tutorial chapter. Morphopolis, true to its nature as a game about insects, has no written language components anywhere. Everything is indicated through a series of visual pop-ups and hand icons, which unfortunately extends to the interface of the game. Just trying to move my insect at the beginning devolved into the hand icon relentlessly mocking me as I tried various clicking, dragging, and clicking-and-dragging motions until I randomly stumbled upon something that worked. It turns out that in order to move the insect, you have to click and hold down on the spot where you want it to move, making the tutorial's hand motion completely misleading.Despite this, once I got used to the demands of having to figure out not only the solution to each puzzle, but what I was trying to accomplish in the first place, I started to get into the rhythm of clicking on bugs, gathering objects, and opening up new pathways to other bugs so I could backtrack and get more objects. The hint feature was helpful; however, one thing that was not helpful was having no hint feature nor exit button on the mini-puzzle segments. The languid pace of the game encouraged me to take my time, however on more than one occasion I had to tab out of the game to look up a guide because literally none of the mouse movements I tried were showing any sign of progress.Each level ends with having to collect the body parts and eggs of a giant insect, after which the grub burrows into its flesh(?), metamorphoses, and gains a new appearance and powers (which are activated by clicking the left mouse button once -- another thing I had to figure out through laborious trial and error). Once I figured out that mechanic, it was fun to use environmental cues to determine what the likely outcomes of using the bug's power would be. The bug got stuck on the environment sometimes, including on the exit of the final level, though the jerky flipping motion at least indicated to me that something unintended was going on.For all the frustration the game gave me, I did finish it, in under two hours. Overall I give it a 6/10, which is a recommendation, but just barely. I enjoyed the core gameplay and setting, immersing myself in the world and the journey of the aphid, but there are way too many omissions of features that would have reduced the amount of times I was simply jarred out of the game by frustration at its minimal interface and sometimes buggy mechanics.

Posted: June 30, 2015
												So, I bought this game on sale for it's visual presentation, and in that area I was not dissapointed; the game is beautiful and does a fantastic job of making you feel like you are in the pages of a storybook. The game itself has some hiccups to work through, though.First of all, the game was designed for a touch screen, and it shows. The all mouse interface is functional, but not ideal. While finding things through the world is fine, the use of the mouse for movement is clunky and can definitely start to grate after a while, especially as you slowly move up and down and back and forth across the levels. Some of the puzzles likewise feel a bit clunky which can push a challenging puzzle over the brink into frustrating. The puzzles themselves are fine, nothing too wild and probably variations of things you've seen before. That's not bad, just know that it's nothing groundbreaking.The game itself is made up of I spy hunts for various items, puzzles, and the occasional interaction with the environment. Again, nothing earth shattering, but functional enough to keep things interesting. Most of the gameplay is made up of hunting for the items on the screen with puzzles being the reward for finding them. Again, these aren't bad things, but don't expect an insect version of Broken Sword. The game is definitely worth playing if you find the art style intriguing. That's what drew me in, and it definitely delivered on that count. The gameplay is nothing to write home about, but with the art and presentation draped over it, it works.

Posted: May 8, 2015
												Artsy hidden object points&click game. The puzzles are decent and the objects are hard enough to find. There is a hint button with a fairly low cooldown that points to a missed object if there is one in the area of use, or plays a sound meaning there is no hidden object here. There is no introduction or hints to the puzzles; you'll have to figure it all out yourself.Very clunky movement/pathing. Have to hold down the mouse button to move. A lot of backtracking and the bug is really slow.The art and music are fantastically atmospheric though. Play for a meditation type entertainment rather than mentally challenging, though some of the puzzles do take some brain work.All achievements are earned on first run. The ingame menu consists of 'to title menu' and 'return to game' and the title menu of chapter select and exit game. So options are extremely limited. There is no save button, and the puzzles have no exit button, so you'll have to restart level if you have to quit. The game is short; only five small levels with 2-6 areas in each. Recommended for the artsy, atmospheric, meditational feeling it has. All the small nuisances makes it not worth its price unless on sale though.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												I'd recommend this for the visual artsy-inclined and those looking for a short, relaxing puzzle experience.Morphopholis is a beautifully drawn, slow paced hidden object/puzzle game. The artwork is gorgeous and vibrant - as you can see from the screenshots. There are a few puzzles scattered throughout, each of which are completely different. They aren't too hard, they make sense and some require thinking (if you're not just brute forcing it!). The game is short, but it remains fresh throughout, which is nicer than long and filled with boring repetition. The movement of your bug is sometimes a bit irritating (especially when you're unsure where to click to move to the next zone), but it works - and you can click your bug to see where it can go, traced with what I assume are visualised ant pheromones...! Also some of the puzzles could do with more intuitive controls (the "checkers" style puzzle especially - you need to click and drag!).All together a pleasant, laid back experience marred slightly by several jammy controls.

Posted: September 6, 2015
												The game "Morphopolis" is a pretty little, short puzzle/hidden objects game that builds on a relaxing atmosphere in a natural, colourful environment (to be more exact: the world of insects).In five levels you take control of an insect trying to get to the end of the level but a row of obstacles get in your way. To get rid of them you need to solve a few puzzles or find a certain amount of objects (which is more challenging than it sounds considering the detailed backgrounds you have to look at to find the objects).What's nice is that the game is quite relaxing which is because of the soothing easy-listening soundtrack and the design which make you feel you're in some sort of jungle right now.You won't get any help in the game on what a puzzle is about but most of the time it's easy to find out. Only the very last puzzle in level 5 is very tricky.Aside from the lack of game help in the game, it can get very annoying when the screen moves and you have to way until the next screen slowly appears (because your insect moves slowly, too).So if you like a short puzzle/hidden objects game for about 1-2 hours and if you don't dislike insects, feel free to entertain yourself. But because it's so short, better keep your eyes open for a discount offer instead of paying full 4,99 € for this game.

Posted: April 12, 2016
												Morphopolis is a very artsy game.  Beautiful and colorful and a little surreal.At it's core it's a hidden object puzzle game where you find objects and then use them on other objects. Sometimes this initiates a puzzle that you have to complete.  Some objects in the environment you need to click on to initiate the ability to go on an object hunt which was a little annoying, though not unfair. Just remember if it looks important click on it once to see if it pops up that it wants something.The game barely has any instructions and mostly you're just on your own.  But despite the lack of any prompts that tell you what to do the game doesn't just leave you hanging as the puzzles do make enough sense that one should be able to piece together what you need to do. I only have problems with one puzzle that I needed to look up how to do it.Morphopolis feels like it was designed to play on a tablet, phone, or any sort of touch screen as the controls are 'click & hold' or 'click & drag' oriented. Though this did not really subtract from the game for me.The game is short (I beat it in about 2 hours) and does not really have any replay value but I still say buy it if you got a couple of extra dollars available. It's a nice little game to waste some time on and it's dang pretty to look at.P.S. You'll 100% the game on your first play-though probably.

Posted: July 3, 2015
												I felt compelled to check out this game when it was on sale for $.19, because how could such a beautiful looking puzzler be only $.19? I'm so glad I did. This is a very small, quirky game, but it's a beautiful little gem well worth your time.The music and hand-drawn insect and nature art create a very peaceful, otherworldly atmosphere to explore. There are no words or text instructions, but the game has a hint button which will highlight your next step if you can't figure out what to do next. Gameplay is basically hidden item-gathering exploration, interspersed with a puzzle in each chapter. The game progresses in a way that feels natural to understand. The puzzles can be tricky, but not impossible, and everything about the game is satisfying when you figure things out on your own. That said, if you get totally stuck on a puzzle and need a nudge in the right direction, check out the excellent Steam guides people have written.Some caveats: There are five chapters, and if you close the game in the middle of a chapter, you'll have to start from the beginning of that chapter again. I can't find this as a flaw since the chapters take so little time to complete (you can finish the game with all achievements in 2-3 hours), but it's something to know before you play.You also can't close the game during a puzzle, but again, most of them don't take very long to solve. One reviewer complained that puzzles have no reset button if you mess them up, but none of them can be messed up except the chapter 4 puzzle, which does have a reset button (the yellow spot on the right of the puzzle).This is a very small, lovely little world to spend a couple of hours in, and I recommend it.

Posted: July 3, 2015
												Beautiful graphics.  Takes about 3 hours to guide your 'insect' through 5 stages.  You have to collect things blended into the background and solve several puzzles.  The game saves after each stage but there is no manual save.  In most cases I dislike that but in this case it would have been excessive.  You just have to relax and imagine you're exploring a new world and take it as it comes.  If you're completely stuck, there is help to find the hidden items but the puzzles just have to be solved.  Great deal for the quality!

The character movements are a bit buggy (pun intented) and jerky at times, which really takes away from the game as a whole. Play this game if you enjoy artsy games like Flow and Flower, or even the 1st level of Spore. It feels a bit like you're looking at a beautiful painting and imagining all the movements in your mind, but they ARE actually happening. Speaking of the graphics, they are very well done, with close up and background objects blurry, and the midground in-focus. This game left me wanting more, as the ending was a bit abrupt. Totally room for expansion if the developers wanted to pursue that, but who knows if that will happen.

Posted: June 27, 2016
												I'm going to give Morphopolis a lukewarm recommendation, because the artwork is gorgeous, and I'm a sucker for both point-and-click adventures and games with a unique visual style.  If those things sound up your alley, then definitely give Morphopolis a try.  I do have reservations though, as the game can become very tedious, as it basically consists of navigating very slow-moving insects between various screens as you look for hidden objects, and solving small puzzles.  The controls are also frustrating at times.  There are five segments to play through, but there is no real ending once you've completed the final puzzle.  Speaking of the final puzzle, it almost caused the game to lose my recommendation, as it is basically an annoying slider puzzle, and I really can't stand when these show up in games.  All of that being said, however, Morphopolis remains a beautiful, relaxing experience, and it's likely worth your time.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Morphopolis is a beautiful, but ultimately unpolished little gem of a game. I got it on sale for about $1. For that price, it is definitely worth it. For anything more, I might not have considered it had I known what I know about it now.First impressions were good; the hand-drawn art is gorgeous and scrolls seamlessly, and the music is okay enough, albeit a little repetitive.My frustration began in the tutorial chapter. Morphopolis, true to its nature as a game about insects, has no written language components anywhere. Everything is indicated through a series of visual pop-ups and hand icons, which unfortunately extends to the interface of the game. Just trying to move my insect at the beginning devolved into the hand icon relentlessly mocking me as I tried various clicking, dragging, and clicking-and-dragging motions until I randomly stumbled upon something that worked. It turns out that in order to move the insect, you have to click and hold down on the spot where you want it to move, making the tutorial's hand motion completely misleading.Despite this, once I got used to the demands of having to figure out not only the solution to each puzzle, but what I was trying to accomplish in the first place, I started to get into the rhythm of clicking on bugs, gathering objects, and opening up new pathways to other bugs so I could backtrack and get more objects. The hint feature was helpful; however, one thing that was not helpful was having no hint feature nor exit button on the mini-puzzle segments. The languid pace of the game encouraged me to take my time, however on more than one occasion I had to tab out of the game to look up a guide because literally none of the mouse movements I tried were showing any sign of progress.Each level ends with having to collect the body parts and eggs of a giant insect, after which the grub burrows into its flesh(?), metamorphoses, and gains a new appearance and powers (which are activated by clicking the left mouse button once -- another thing I had to figure out through laborious trial and error). Once I figured out that mechanic, it was fun to use environmental cues to determine what the likely outcomes of using the bug's power would be. The bug got stuck on the environment sometimes, including on the exit of the final level, though the jerky flipping motion at least indicated to me that something unintended was going on.For all the frustration the game gave me, I did finish it, in under two hours. Overall I give it a 6/10, which is a recommendation, but just barely. I enjoyed the core gameplay and setting, immersing myself in the world and the journey of the aphid, but there are way too many omissions of features that would have reduced the amount of times I was simply jarred out of the game by frustration at its minimal interface and sometimes buggy mechanics.

Posted: February 16, 2016
												Horribly designed game. Controls are confusing. Don't let the amazing art sell you on this game, it is not fun. A lot of the game is clicking, clicking, clicking. The puzzles give you zero direction.  A lot of game elements that are necessary to advance I discovered by boringly clicking around the screen to see if anything would happen. Unless your time is absolutely worthless do not invest it in this game.Not to mention, NO SAVES.  So if you are stuck in a level and you need to stop gaming for whatever reason, you literally have to start over since your only pause options are to go to the main menu or quit the game. I mean its mind boggling how many design flaws this game has while still managing to have a popular rating.

Posted: February 4, 2016
												I absolutely love this game.  It's simple, it's short, and it's very relaxing to play.  I finished the whole thing in one sitting and was left wanting so much more.  While I'm not typically a fan of the find-the-thing game category, this one was beautiful.  It's exotic, innocent, the art is great and the music matches it exquisitely.  I feel like I ripped them off for paying so little.  It's only good for maybe an hour or two of actual play time but good god it's fun while it lasts.  The only downside, and I say this with no disparagement, is that some of the puzzles are not self-evident.  This isn't usually too much of a condemnation except that the game provides virtually no instructions at any point.  Of course, there's Google.  If you're at an absolute loss, do that.  There's a brief how to move sequence at the very beginning and the rest is up for you to figure out.  That being said, just get it.  It's so cheap.  There's really no way to go wrong with this one.  Even if it was just an art and music pack without a game at all it'd still be worthwhile.  If I can pay a dollar for over an hour of childlike wonder then I just won and that's exactly what Morphopolis brings to the table in the most beautiful, multicoloured and delightful way possible.  It's such a beautifully and richly put together game that I can't recommend it enough.

Posted: April 15, 2015
												The atmospheric soundtrack and the very beautiful visual environment art attracted my interest and kept me playing the game from the beginning till the end.The game lasts around 3 hours (maybe much less if you are used to solving puzzles) and its divided in 5 levels/stages in which there are 8 puzzles in total. Some of them are easy and some needs time and good attention/focus to solve them. The last one is more challenging, something like a soft version of Rubik's cube (but with insects)!At the gameplay you take the role of an insect that evolves/transforms after each level/stage of the game. Its a point and click game, you don't use keyboard, and you collect various of objects to feed them to some other insects that are blocking your way forward and during this you will encounter to solve these 8 puzzles that I mention before.TL;DR: Its a nice point and click adventure and puzzle game with very beautiful art and atmospheric soundtrack. It lasts around 2-3 hours and it has 5 levels and 8 puzzles in total. If it worths the full price... idk, it depends on the person. I bought it -95% only to farm the cards but I really liked the game and I played it till the end!Cons: Its really short game. It could have had more levels and puzzles.9/10

Posted: September 1, 2015
												Although some may commend it for its beautiful art style; the gameplay is infuriating, unrewarding, and far too slow for me to really appreciate all Morphopolis has to offer. There also isn't a menu where I can tinker with the sounds, which means I have to listen to that annoying bug chirp in the background for the entirety of the game.The controls are maddening. You click and drag your cursor in the direction that you want the bug to move, but unfortunately the controls don't always work. You'll find yourself dragging, only to watch your bug go back and forth. In certain points, you'll have to wait for an animation to finish until you can move your bug again - which can be upsetting if the controls are screwing up constantly. There is also tons of backtracking, which makes every level feel tedious. Since every level that you play seems to end with you collecting a serious of orange balls, I know that I am going to have to do that at the end, but I can't collect them all before I receive the quest. Subsequently, I'm forced to backtrack through every single level to collect all of the orange balls in order to go to the next level that will ask me to do the same thing.Backtracking wouldn't be that much of an issue if your character didn't trek along at the speed of molasses. The two hours that you'll spend completing this game could be cut down to about an hour and half if the bug would move just a tad bit quicker. Unfortunately, that never happens and you're forced to watch your bug move uncomfortably slow through every area - which can be upsetting if you're someone that enjoys gameplay that actually moves at an appropriate pace.Also, the last puzzle is a treat. By that, I mean, you'll be shouting at your computer screen and wondering why the hell anyone would develop a puzzle as ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as the one you're playing. In the end, Morphopolis is slow, boring, and unrewarding - the gameplay is too little movement, too much grinding and that's just no fun. I cannot recommend this game.

Posted: March 19, 2016
												After finishing the game, I was rather neutral on the whole experience. Several aspects were done very well, but unfortunately just as many aspects were poorly executed.ProsGreat art, always a wonder to look at.High variety in puzzles.Unique and clever game design.Cheap, and even on sale often!Perfect for your biology gooroo/lover.Puzzle lovers will have a blast with this game.Sticks to its format and its formulated basics down to a perfection.Cons No explanation on how controls work outside a brief cursor swipe or two.Music is, albeit well made, annoying and repetitive after hearing the same instruments used repeadetly.Certain puzzles can become infurriating difficult while others are extremely simple, losing any feel of progressive difficulty.Some sound effects are loud and annoying, especially the fluttering bugs at the last level This may be done on purpose, though it is still a con The game turned black once I beat the last level and got the achievment, making the ending anti-climatic (I'm not sure if this was a glitch or not...?)Movement is really slow and tedious, and moving from environment-to-environment is forced, so one mistake and you'll be stuck watching your bug move to an undesired location.Neutral/extrasThe game was short (1.2 hours at the most for me). Means you won't take much time to finish this (this may be a pro or con depending on the person)Scientific names for each level achievement! Cool!No story involved here, just a play and watch game.Has card drops for trading cards! (More games need these...)A little difficult to reccomend to many people with the varies of biological and puzzle elements mixed together.VerdictSince the game is hard to recommend and has some bugs and issues here and there, but gets the basics down very well, I'd say this is a mixed rating. If puzzle games and wildlife peak your interest, then go for it, else you won't be missing much if you skip this game.Rating: 6/10, slightly above average.

Posted: September 2, 2016
												full disclosure - i don't play hidden object games, and didn't realise this was one when i decided to play it next. i thought it was a puzzle game. i was wrong.i won't criticise it for it's hidden object content (though i do not understand the appeal at all) as it's unfair to mark down a game for being the genre it is. however, the other aspects are incredibly frustrating. the character model moves so slowly, which feels like unnecessary padding. pathing is terrible. there's no indication of where you can and can't go, so you have to wait an eternity for the character model to walk to a point only to find you can't go that way. the game doesn't explain any of the mechanics or puzzles - not an issue for the most part, but in 2 instances i had no idea what i had to do to move the game along and had to look at a guide to simply progress the game (oh, that mechanic that i discovered by accident that did nothing now does something in select spots on one single level? ugh). that's not clever game design.the puzzles were fairly bland - nothing that hasn't been done a million times before. but i have to mention the last one in the game...if you're colour blind, like i am - GOOD BLOODY LUCK. it was nearly impossible for me to distinguish some of the colours. terrible puzzle design.the music is nice enough, but loops too soon.visually - A+. absolutely beautiful to look at. just wish the graphics were married to a better game.

Posted: July 3, 2015
												I felt compelled to check out this game when it was on sale for $.19, because how could such a beautiful looking puzzler be only $.19? I'm so glad I did. This is a very small, quirky game, but it's a beautiful little gem well worth your time.The music and hand-drawn insect and nature art create a very peaceful, otherworldly atmosphere to explore. There are no words or text instructions, but the game has a hint button which will highlight your next step if you can't figure out what to do next. Gameplay is basically hidden item-gathering exploration, interspersed with a puzzle in each chapter. The game progresses in a way that feels natural to understand. The puzzles can be tricky, but not impossible, and everything about the game is satisfying when you figure things out on your own. That said, if you get totally stuck on a puzzle and need a nudge in the right direction, check out the excellent Steam guides people have written.Some caveats: There are five chapters, and if you close the game in the middle of a chapter, you'll have to start from the beginning of that chapter again. I can't find this as a flaw since the chapters take so little time to complete (you can finish the game with all achievements in 2-3 hours), but it's something to know before you play.You also can't close the game during a puzzle, but again, most of them don't take very long to solve. One reviewer complained that puzzles have no reset button if you mess them up, but none of them can be messed up except the chapter 4 puzzle, which does have a reset button (the yellow spot on the right of the puzzle).This is a very small, lovely little world to spend a couple of hours in, and I recommend it.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Morphopolis is a beautiful, but ultimately unpolished little gem of a game. I got it on sale for about $1. For that price, it is definitely worth it. For anything more, I might not have considered it had I known what I know about it now.First impressions were good; the hand-drawn art is gorgeous and scrolls seamlessly, and the music is okay enough, albeit a little repetitive.My frustration began in the tutorial chapter. Morphopolis, true to its nature as a game about insects, has no written language components anywhere. Everything is indicated through a series of visual pop-ups and hand icons, which unfortunately extends to the interface of the game. Just trying to move my insect at the beginning devolved into the hand icon relentlessly mocking me as I tried various clicking, dragging, and clicking-and-dragging motions until I randomly stumbled upon something that worked. It turns out that in order to move the insect, you have to click and hold down on the spot where you want it to move, making the tutorial's hand motion completely misleading.Despite this, once I got used to the demands of having to figure out not only the solution to each puzzle, but what I was trying to accomplish in the first place, I started to get into the rhythm of clicking on bugs, gathering objects, and opening up new pathways to other bugs so I could backtrack and get more objects. The hint feature was helpful; however, one thing that was not helpful was having no hint feature nor exit button on the mini-puzzle segments. The languid pace of the game encouraged me to take my time, however on more than one occasion I had to tab out of the game to look up a guide because literally none of the mouse movements I tried were showing any sign of progress.Each level ends with having to collect the body parts and eggs of a giant insect, after which the grub burrows into its flesh(?), metamorphoses, and gains a new appearance and powers (which are activated by clicking the left mouse button once -- another thing I had to figure out through laborious trial and error). Once I figured out that mechanic, it was fun to use environmental cues to determine what the likely outcomes of using the bug's power would be. The bug got stuck on the environment sometimes, including on the exit of the final level, though the jerky flipping motion at least indicated to me that something unintended was going on.For all the frustration the game gave me, I did finish it, in under two hours. Overall I give it a 6/10, which is a recommendation, but just barely. I enjoyed the core gameplay and setting, immersing myself in the world and the journey of the aphid, but there are way too many omissions of features that would have reduced the amount of times I was simply jarred out of the game by frustration at its minimal interface and sometimes buggy mechanics.

Posted: August 16, 2015
Summary Pretty nice hidden object game with a lovely aesthetic and some decent mini-game puzzles, but with janky controls and a nonexistent story. Worth it at a low price for fans of the genre. Long story  Morphopolis is a pretty hidden object game. If you do not like hidden object games, do not buy. You play as various iterations of insects that are moving through the world at a very slow pace for… some reason. As far as I can tell there is no story to the game, just a series of hidden object games and mini-puzzles set in a relatively pretty world. For me that was fine.My biggest problem with the game was the awful movement controls. You hold down the mouse courser to move instead of just clicking; this results in some awkward dancing and can lead you to incorrectly assume that you cannot move further along a path. The movement is also way too slow and there is no option to double click to change scenes quickly, which artificially prolongs the game by forcing you to crawl back and forth between scenes. The game also does a relatively poor job of explaining the mini-game puzzle rules as well as some important mechanics which can lead to some frustration. For example you can click on your own character which will is essential to reveal items in some chapters, but as far as I know that is never mentioned in the tutorial. Still, if you can get it cheap (I got it as part of the art appreciation pack for 0.44 Euro) and you like hidden object games, why not? It’s not a great game, but it was worth the two hours I spent on it.

Posted: September 13, 2016
												Decent game. A pretty and relaxing object finder and puzzle game. The bug moves slow, but that fits the tone of the game. Most of the game is pretty intuitive, which is good ‘cuz there’s no instructions. Kinda short, only takes about 1-2 hours to complete. Also little replay value, but you can get it pretty cheap, so not too unreasonable. Pretty sure you get all the achievements just by playing though the game once, so a good game for people who care about that sort of thing. Only real problem I had is once you open one of the puzzles afaik you have to either solve it or ctrl-alt-delete out of the game. Seems like poor game design. Spoilers! One content warning: The bug you are / are guiding eats its way into a few dead bugs. It’s not graphic in any way, and it is perfectly natural for a bug, but it might disturb someone who is very easily grossed out, or someone who really doesn’t like bugs.

Morphopolis is a click game, and you need to click to control/find any insects/item to complete or unlock some puzzles.The art also pretty amazing. Posted: February 7, 2016
												Morphopolis, a beautiful hidden object game. ProsThe artwork is stunning, as an art piece, this game achieves everything I would want. The hidden objects are for the most part, fairly easy to indentify. allowing you to take in the artworkThe music slides into the background easily. ConsThe controls are rough. They work perfectly fine, but many times I found them rather counter-intuitive. You move painfully slow, and for many of the levels, you need to do a bit of backtracking to find objects previously obscured. Combined, this leads to a very relaxed, and on occasion too relaxed travel time. Overall, I loved it. I would definitely recommend it, especially if you enjoy the hidden object genre. However, if this is going to be your first forey into this style of game, put it on your wishlist, play some of the many more polished, and/or free games that are around. And come back to this one later.

Posted: February 4, 2016
												I absolutely love this game.  It's simple, it's short, and it's very relaxing to play.  I finished the whole thing in one sitting and was left wanting so much more.  While I'm not typically a fan of the find-the-thing game category, this one was beautiful.  It's exotic, innocent, the art is great and the music matches it exquisitely.  I feel like I ripped them off for paying so little.  It's only good for maybe an hour or two of actual play time but good god it's fun while it lasts.  The only downside, and I say this with no disparagement, is that some of the puzzles are not self-evident.  This isn't usually too much of a condemnation except that the game provides virtually no instructions at any point.  Of course, there's Google.  If you're at an absolute loss, do that.  There's a brief how to move sequence at the very beginning and the rest is up for you to figure out.  That being said, just get it.  It's so cheap.  There's really no way to go wrong with this one.  Even if it was just an art and music pack without a game at all it'd still be worthwhile.  If I can pay a dollar for over an hour of childlike wonder then I just won and that's exactly what Morphopolis brings to the table in the most beautiful, multicoloured and delightful way possible.  It's such a beautifully and richly put together game that I can't recommend it enough.

Posted: April 4, 2016
												I have to admit: I have not finished this game. I had to give up when I encountered the last puzzle. Was too hard to overcome for me. But will I come back sometime to finish what I started? Indeed I think so.Morphopolis is very simple game. You only need to click at certain objects in order to move "story" forward. It uses oldschool mechanics from simillar games, so it is not innovative at any point. I have a feeling that it is specially designed to be longer than it had to be. You will often find yourself wandering around the same locations just to pick a mushroom that you couldn't pick last time you were there. Also game is very short in it's core "story".But Morphopolis is beautiful. Really. And has so relaxing and nice music. It is great way to spend 2/3 hours. Not more though, unless you won't be bored doing the same thing over and over again.I can easily recommend this game and give it 7/10.Pro:- price- graphics- music- conceptCon:- too short- takes too much space- is designed to be longer than it should be

Posted: July 16, 2016
												Not exactly sure what just happened but it wasn’t bad.Story:You’re a bug that needs to give eggs to a different bug and then in the next level you play it? I’m not sure if I understood that correctly but overall, no story.Gameplay:It’s a point and click where the objective is to collect things. You get quests by clicking on insects which tell you to collect things which open paths (sometimes) to other insects and collectibles. It’s a simple process really. The fetch quests aren’t too bad as the entire game is about exploration. At the end, you just move on to a different level. Each level has about 4 rooms and you backtrack a lot which isn’t too much of a problem as they are small but your speed is low. Controlling the movement of the bug seems really not that accurate but you usually just use it to move to a different screen. Sometimes there are mini puzzles that show up like connecting ropes, matching colors, or a literal puzzle. They aren’t too annoying but just seem like time lengthens (except the last one can go ♥♥♥♥ itself).Overall, the gameplay is simple and not that bad. Graphics/Performance: (with a 970, 4790K, 16GB of RAM, SSD)The game looks fantastic and maintains a solid 60. Everything seems handdrawn and the sheer detail is just amazing. However, there are black bars around the top and bottom which are annoying. There isn’t a setting menu for resolution, controls (although a mouse is all you need), or music which is annoying. The music itself is really nice and nature-y (?) while having a sense of foreboding. Final Thoughts:I liked it. It was different and interesting. Overall, worth a look although wait for a sale.

Posted: July 30, 2016
												I really wasn't expecting this game to be very good when I picked it up dirt-cheap on sale. The art style looked weird (in a good way) and the idea of playing as a bug (who crawls so bloody sloooow I might add) seemed a bit strange too. However, I'd just joined Steam properly (I made my account 6 years ago and never used it) and needed a few games to get me started. I was pleasantly surprised by this game. It wasn't long at all. Five chapters/levels in total, each lasting around 15-30 minutes each, depending on your puzzle skills.   The game plays like a triple-mix of platformer/hidden-object/puzzle game, with the end-goal in each chapter being to evolve your bug to the next stage in it's life.  The puzzles are fairly simple, but some can become a bit tricky as there is no guide or text to tell you what you should be doing to solve each one. I would recommend this game to others,  as I had fun while it lasted, and the level design is very nice on the eye. Great work.

Posted: September 2, 2016
												full disclosure - i don't play hidden object games, and didn't realise this was one when i decided to play it next. i thought it was a puzzle game. i was wrong.i won't criticise it for it's hidden object content (though i do not understand the appeal at all) as it's unfair to mark down a game for being the genre it is. however, the other aspects are incredibly frustrating. the character model moves so slowly, which feels like unnecessary padding. pathing is terrible. there's no indication of where you can and can't go, so you have to wait an eternity for the character model to walk to a point only to find you can't go that way. the game doesn't explain any of the mechanics or puzzles - not an issue for the most part, but in 2 instances i had no idea what i had to do to move the game along and had to look at a guide to simply progress the game (oh, that mechanic that i discovered by accident that did nothing now does something in select spots on one single level? ugh). that's not clever game design.the puzzles were fairly bland - nothing that hasn't been done a million times before. but i have to mention the last one in the game...if you're colour blind, like i am - GOOD BLOODY LUCK. it was nearly impossible for me to distinguish some of the colours. terrible puzzle design.the music is nice enough, but loops too soon.visually - A+. absolutely beautiful to look at. just wish the graphics were married to a better game.

Posted: September 8, 2016
												TLDR: The art alone is worth the price of this game (especially on sale), but don't expect to be blown away by the gameplay.----------------------Long review:First off let me say that I love puzzle games, and I'm always a sucker for an artistic or atmospheric game, even if the gameplay is trivial. I was ready to love this game. Unfortunately it has some serious shortcomings that prohibit me from loving it.The art is amazing, we all agree on that. The artists spent a lot of time on it, and it's obvious that the whole team had a great idea for a game. The bad part is the controls. They are so bad. Like why, WHY can't I just use WASD to control the bug? Click and hold is terrible. Even if it's designed for touch screen, that is still a terrible way to move around. Frequently (the whole time) I would be clicking for an item, and accidentally move to the adjacent frame. Which you can't cancel, you have to wait for the animation, then go back to where you were. Super annoying. Also getting around the environment is not very intuitive, and it's not always clear that there are pathways to other areas. This could be considered a pro if you're into exploration, but the controls are so slow and annoying that it isn't fun at all to explore. Then many of the puzzles suffer from♥♥♥♥♥♥controls as well. The last puzzle was infuriating, and would have been pretty easy with proper controls.Which leads into another downfall... poor puzzle design. Some were good. The moth mosaic was very satisfying, and I would absolutely play a game consisting solely of that puzzle. Others were just straight up annoying or felt like busy work.In any case, this game is cheap, and it was worth it to me to support the devs with less money than I would give to a homeless person, even if it was for the art alone. I had some fun in the short amount of time it took me to beat it. I look forward to what they come up with in the future, and I hope that they manage the gameplay a little better for future projects.

Posted: May 23, 2015
												This game can seem quite complex due to the lack of a tutorial (all you get is a few hand indications at the beginning and then are expected to know what to do from there). Also, just a heads up, there is no explanation on how to solve the puzzles but if you tinker around you tend to figure them out for yourself. There are 5 levels that generally stay the same difficulty but only grow with more "tasks" (i.e. collect petals, etc). You're bug form changes with each level and does get some "special abilities" with the different morphs  (i.e. buzzing your wings to blow away petals so you can recover seeds, that sort of thing)  Overall, I would say its a 7.5/10Pros:-Beautiful scenery-Nice music-Decent conceptCons:-No explanations on how to solve puzzles (but if you play a lot of Artifex Mundi games you probably stand a better chance)-Extremely short (i got a perfect game in under an hour......)Ehs:-Movement is weird-You are incredibly slow which is probably to make the game last longer -What exactly are we doing to the giant bugs at the end of the levels? 												The game points on the music and the graphic.The music is simply awesome .... this is why I left the intro menu for 10 + minutes even if the tutorial arrow wanted me to click on the first puzzle so badly. The tutorial is short, basicly you have to click everywhere. The thing that is not showed in the short tutorial is that you have different maps and you'll reach them by moving your bug in that direction (sometimes it bugs a bit .... but you know, it's a game of bugs so they wanted friends XD).The game is quite easy both in the mechanic and game itself but it's still cute and interesting in some of its parts. In 2 hours it was sadly finished.... I want to start it again....Some puzzles where tricky because you need to use your brain and try to click slide or what else (click and slide stop).There are no bosses or evil insects here in this game, everything is really peaceful. You climb leaves flowers and insect themselves to help the others with their own issues by clicking the required items to collect them and bring them to the bug in need.The music is really awesome with the hang drum or pan, but after a while it can be boring if you'll spend a lot of time searching THAT tiny little item that you cannot see.The morphism of the insect is not an evolution of your starting little bug, as I've thought and maybe you too, but after you finish a level, you'll use a different one.Overall I love it and I complitely recommend this game, thoug I was hoping it has more than 5 levels Y_Y...

Gameplay controls are exceedingly clunky.  No way to part way through a level (re-playing the first part isn't a challenge, but is tedious), once you are in a puzzle. Posted: December 26, 2015
												8/10 objective rating PROS:- Visually rich- Puzzles are varied enough- Soundtrack is pleasant to listen to- Sound design is solid- PriceCONS:- A little short (can be completed in 2-3 hours)- May take the entire first level to understand how this game wants to be played (there are no word prompts so some may find it difficult to understand what is being asked of them)- Some may find the pacing slow---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Morphopolis isn't the most challenging game I've played, nor is it the most interesting "story" wise, but I really enjoyed the art style and the overall feel. The music playing throughout was excellent and very pleasant to listen to. It varies with each level but sounds like one cohesive series.It IS a slow paced game, with 5 levels taking about 2 hours, but I still liked this, as it allowed me to really soak in the artistry and look a everything in detail. That being said, there were times I was sighing at the slowness of the insect I was controlling when I went up a plant for the 4th time. You will have to crawl back and forth between areas often.There isn't a proper tutorial and without word prompting, it was initially difficult to understand what the game wanted me to do. There was also no indication of what my insect character's "powers" were so I got stuck a few times and wasted time going between spots looking for things that I could not see without using said "powers" I discovered these abilities entirely by accident. Note that this could just be my fault and not the game's. This was my first game of this genre since the 90's and maybe I just required a little more hand-holding than most for the beginning.Adjust expectations before starting this game and I think anyone who likes puzzle games will thoroughly enjoy Morphopolis. If you expect action and puzzles that really get you scratching your head for 30 minutes each, you will likely be disappointed!Would have loved 10 levels instead of 5 so I could spend a little more time in this world, but for a quarter (yes, just 25 cents!) I definitely got my money's worth!

Posted: July 17, 2015
												I can't complain since I bought this for 19 cents.  That's basically me selling two steam trading cards.The feeling the game gives off... I don't how many of you remember "The Very Hungry Caterpillar," but it invokes that same kind of nostalgic blast of color, something that mesmerizes you.  It is more than ten times as bright and vivid as that book, but as adults that's what it takes to overload your senses.  At the same time there is an ever-present sensation of faded-ness.  Like the bright colors are constantly waning and all your efforts is only leading you to the end of both the game and your buggy life.The game play is nothing special.  It is just a point and click with a few puzzles.Note:  Screw the beetle lock!  That took me half an hour.  That's 25% of the time spent on this game wasted on a bland rock with five bugs on it!

Posted: May 8, 2015
												Artsy hidden object points&click game. The puzzles are decent and the objects are hard enough to find. There is a hint button with a fairly low cooldown that points to a missed object if there is one in the area of use, or plays a sound meaning there is no hidden object here. There is no introduction or hints to the puzzles; you'll have to figure it all out yourself.Very clunky movement/pathing. Have to hold down the mouse button to move. A lot of backtracking and the bug is really slow.The art and music are fantastically atmospheric though. Play for a meditation type entertainment rather than mentally challenging, though some of the puzzles do take some brain work.All achievements are earned on first run. The ingame menu consists of 'to title menu' and 'return to game' and the title menu of chapter select and exit game. So options are extremely limited. There is no save button, and the puzzles have no exit button, so you'll have to restart level if you have to quit. The game is short; only five small levels with 2-6 areas in each. Recommended for the artsy, atmospheric, meditational feeling it has. All the small nuisances makes it not worth its price unless on sale though.

												As far as a game goes, this is not a very good one. As far as art, visual, and music ... that is a totally different story.The "gameplay" is very simple, and I'm not sure I would call it a "puzzle game" so much a find it. The music has a nice peaceful tone to it through the entire thing, and the visuals largely speak for themselves - beautiful. The story, and, yes, there is technically a story, is very strange, as well as simple, but effective when you think about it for a couple seconds. Morphopolis something to look at and admire, but not really interact with.  Not something I can recomend ... as a game. It is, howerver, something I can recomend as a short, peaceful experience that many people might find enjoyable. Take that as you will.

Posted: July 30, 2016
												I really wasn't expecting this game to be very good when I picked it up dirt-cheap on sale. The art style looked weird (in a good way) and the idea of playing as a bug (who crawls so bloody sloooow I might add) seemed a bit strange too. However, I'd just joined Steam properly (I made my account 6 years ago and never used it) and needed a few games to get me started. I was pleasantly surprised by this game. It wasn't long at all. Five chapters/levels in total, each lasting around 15-30 minutes each, depending on your puzzle skills.   The game plays like a triple-mix of platformer/hidden-object/puzzle game, with the end-goal in each chapter being to evolve your bug to the next stage in it's life.  The puzzles are fairly simple, but some can become a bit tricky as there is no guide or text to tell you what you should be doing to solve each one. I would recommend this game to others,  as I had fun while it lasted, and the level design is very nice on the eye. Great work.

Posted: October 24, 2015
												Positives:-The music is very relaxing.-The art is pretty.-Some of the puzzles are pretty fun, and you feel pretty smart for having solved them.-Nice if you like "find the hidden object"-type games.Negatives:-The controls for moving are crap.  Half the time you won't even realize you can go somewhere until you accidentally hold the mouse in the wrong area.  Other times, your bug keeps moving back and forth in the same spot as you try to find the place that'll make it go not just right, but right and downwards.  Sometimes you'll try clicking an object and end up moving your bug back over to the other screen for no apparent reason, even though you weren't clicking in that direction.-On a similar note, you are SLOW.  Slow, slow, slow, slow, SLOW.  Which wouldn't be SO bad, but since you're constantly moving back and forth between screens (using the same crummy controls) to find stuff you missed, it's just unbearable.  I feel like the game would have been at least a half an hour shorter if I could change screens faster.-So much random clicking to figure out what's important.  See, you don't actually find out what you need to collect until you click on something, like another bug, or a plant.  Sorta like they're giving you a quest.  Usually it's easy enough to figure out what needs clicking, but other times, you have no freaking idea how you're supposed to progress without taking a hint.-By level three, you'll start to recognize that the weird orange orbs are gonna need collecting before you can burrow into your next target's brain.  But no, you can't grab anything you know you're gonna need until after the 'quest' is given to you, forcing you to slowly, SLOWLY backtrack through all of the screens to grab them.  I don't mean to sound impatient, but God.  Crawl across the screen a little faster, bug.  Come on!  Hustle, hustle!-No idea where the "pathways" to the next screen are.  Have fun crawling (SLOWLY) across the screen, only to realize it's a dead end.  Then crawl (SLOWLY) back, not sure whether there's another screen, or if you're just bad at finding items.-Did I mention that you're slow?  Because you're slow.  SO FREAKING SLOW.-A couple puzzles are really annoying for the wrong reasons.  For example, the flower puzzle gives you no indication of the controls.  I spent ages clicking around and hoping something would happen, but nope!  It's actually a Chinese Checkers-style puzzle where you have to try and get all but one of the seed thingies to disappear, but without a walkthrough, I never would have figured out the rules and controls.  Figuring out what the freaking puzzle is isn't a puzzle.-No mid-level saves.  Levels aren't usually that long, but if you get stuck on something and call it quits for the night, have fun slowly, slowly, SLOWLY crawling across the screen several more times to complete the initial collection quests again.  SLOWLY.-I don't know if I just accidentally skipped it, or what (in which case it shouldn't be so easy to accidentally skip, because I'm not gonna freaking replay that last puzzle just to see it) but I went into the place I was supposed to go, and... That was it.  The game just ended.  I got an achievement, and then I was back at the menu.  Ghosts 'n' Goblins had a better ending than that!Summary:If you can get it on sale and really, REALLY like hidden object games, it might be worth it, but there are plenty of free games on the internet that aren't so, well, SLOW.  Seriously, I'm not kidding, it's really gonna get on your nerves.  Don't even think about paying the full five dollars for this.  I mean, I appreciate the effort the developers put into it, and everything, but this isn't worth two dollars and fifty cents per hour.

Product received for free
Buy it for the aesthetics!The biggest plus point of the game is it's art. And the soothing soundtracks.I loved it and that was the main reason I got myself to playing it.If the aesthetics of the game don't sell it to you, Morphopolis probably isn't for you.There are total 5 chapters in the game and each chapter has 1 hidden object puzzle and 1-2 some other puzzle.Out of those, I had difficulty solving only one or two of them. The rest weren't that difficult.And completing each chapter gives you an achievement. (So completing the game adds a +1 to your perfect games. Are you listening, achievement hunters? :P )Another good thing is the length of the gameplay (3-4hrs max)If it was any longer, it might've gotten boring. (Unless you're a geek who likes to keep solving puzzles :P )But the length is enough for the art and music to hold you till the end.

												This game works much better as art than it does a game, but it does have some game elements.The main themes the game uses is point-and-click collecting of items on the screen, in addition to the occasional mini-game. It's fairly casual, and might take you a few hours to complete the game. There's no central story that I remember picking up on. Each level follows a different bug that you control, moving around several maps to collect items.Don't expect a whole lot from this game; it's very clear that most of the work went into the graphics, so expect vibrant graphics and basic functionality. I would personally recommend waiting for the game to go under $1 before buying.
