Posted: April 19, 2016
												Went in with the same expectations as Tiny Bang Story and Botanicula, but it wasn't quite up there. GameplayYou take control of small insects and you crawl into bigger insects to revive them, which then crawl into bigger insects etc. The game is inspired by games like Machinarium, Botanicula and Tiny Bang Story. It definitely shows! The biggest flaw this game are the controls. They feel stiff and sometimes boring. Your character moves slow and it can be quite frustrating to collect stuff, because you have to wait for the next picture to pan.GraphicsCartoonish art style is the best way to describe this game. It is obvious to see it is drawn by hand with these lucid and fantasy colors. It is a perfect interpretation of what is like being on drugs. It's not my cup of tea, but it definitely has an unique art style.SoundSoundtrack is relaxing, just as it should. You can tell it is here they drew a lot of inspiration from Tiny Bang Story, which is one my favorite soundtracks of all time. Beautiful piano medleys throughout the whole game.VerdictIt is definitely not as good as the more mainstream point-and-click adventure games, but it never claims to be. It is a fun and short game, which all fans of these types of game should experience. The price is definitely worth it too.

Posted: January 7
												Morphopolis is an art piece more than a game. The gameplay mechanics are poor at best.Pros: The artwork and soundtrack are beautiful.Cons: The gameplay is abysmal. The "mechanics" might work well on a tablet but I doubt it. Most of this game centers around terrible 80s and 90s video game tropes related to adventure games, those being Find The Hidden Object/Pixels and Solve The Puzzle With No Context.This game seems to be an art student's impression of what would make a great game, sadly, it's nothing more than an abject failure.

Posted: January 4
												I have mixed feelings about Morphopolis. Review with points would be fairer: 3/5 pts.Well, graphics are cool, with colorful illustrations and good complexity for the environments. The music is relaxing and each scenario makes me curious about some things of bug's universe... And I really enjoyed most puzzles.BUT, the gameplay needs REAL improvements. It's not intuitive, on first level I need to click every thing to understand what does what. I just got the tricks somewhere in levels 3-4. And some other puzzles made me VERY nervous (specially the last one, awekened the worst in me), the ones that need strategic moves to beat.So, if you are impatient, better not get this, for the gameplay and puzzles. But I recommend this game if you really REALLY  R E A L L Y  enjoy puzzles. Then, if you have a bit of patience and want to relax and admire a beautiful art for a couple of hours, that's for you (:

Posted: April 16
TL;DRThe game looks gorgeous but plays terribly. Add that to the fact that the gameplay isn't that memorable to start with and I'd suggest giving this game a hard pass.Buggy ControlsWhen the hardest part of your point-n'-click game is moving around, you should know you have an issue with the design. I do not understand the rationale behind requiring the player to hold down a mouse button to move. No only that, the controls are so jittery that it's quite easy to transition from one screen to the next and simply have the screen slide right back. And god forbid you try to navigate a three way intersection just to watch your bug sit there and spin aimlessly.As for the gameplay itself, it's mediocre. The "I Spy" hidden object sections of the levels are either cakewalks (bright yellow objects on green leaves) or unfairly difficult (brown bug on brown tree bark where 90% of the bug is obstructed by a leaf). Them the puzzles: aside from the first and last puzzles, everything else in between is quite juvenile. Clearly, the entire budget of this game was spent on the Art Department and the Level Designers were just mops with a face drawn on.BreakdownPros At Least it Looks Nice: so it's got that going for itCons What's Gameplay? To say this game had any reasonable amount of gameplay would be lying. Time spent in this game breaks down as such: 10% puzzles, 10% clicking things, 80% moving around doing nothing. Use the Arrow Keys: such a simple thing: just let me use the arrow keys to move around, not some janky "click on hold" systemScore: 2/10

Posted: April 16
TL;DRThe game looks gorgeous but plays terribly. Add that to the fact that the gameplay isn't that memorable to start with and I'd suggest giving this game a hard pass.Buggy ControlsWhen the hardest part of your point-n'-click game is moving around, you should know you have an issue with the design. I do not understand the rationale behind requiring the player to hold down a mouse button to move. No only that, the controls are so jittery that it's quite easy to transition from one screen to the next and simply have the screen slide right back. And god forbid you try to navigate a three way intersection just to watch your bug sit there and spin aimlessly.As for the gameplay itself, it's mediocre. The "I Spy" hidden object sections of the levels are either cakewalks (bright yellow objects on green leaves) or unfairly difficult (brown bug on brown tree bark where 90% of the bug is obstructed by a leaf). Them the puzzles: aside from the first and last puzzles, everything else in between is quite juvenile. Clearly, the entire budget of this game was spent on the Art Department and the Level Designers were just mops with a face drawn on.BreakdownPros At Least it Looks Nice: so it's got that going for itCons What's Gameplay? To say this game had any reasonable amount of gameplay would be lying. Time spent in this game breaks down as such: 10% puzzles, 10% clicking things, 80% moving around doing nothing. Use the Arrow Keys: such a simple thing: just let me use the arrow keys to move around, not some janky "click on hold" systemScore: 2/10

content:
Posted: February 22
												It's going to make you want to re-play Botanicula. It's artstyle is definitly it's strongest point, It's got sort of a yellow submarine vibe. Soundtrack fits and that's pretty much it. It's your standard point and click kleptomaniac adventure, you play as an insect who's trying to do an impression of russian nesting dolls by routinely taking over the brains of vegative insects and piloting them into larger insects. There are a couple of clever minigames inbetween the cleptomainiac collecting but there just aren't enough. Sort of my problem with the whole game really, it feels way too short and yet still feels incredibly  padded in every area.Point and click adventure games are one of the oldest forms of game, yet developers still manage to ♥♥♥♥ them up. The walk speed is horrible and the puzzles are never based off logic, although I do like how the game just tells you what objects you need to progress, (rather than doing the normal adventure game rigamarole of throwing every item at a door in the hope it somehow creates progress) it does get pretty boring.It's a shame really, I like the concept, and the art style and music are good and it's got a lot of heart in it; it just stumbles, tripps and♥♥♥♥♥♥s itself in the gameplay and story division.

Posted: June 8, 2016
												Lacks a mid-level save feature, and some levels are very lengthy. Easy to accidentally 'quit' through the use of non-sense arbitrary menu icons instead of text. Does not warn you that you will lose what may amount to 45-60 minutes of gameplay. Controls are god-awful, your insect moves painfully slowly, and will often refuse to follow the commnds of your cursor, deciding to go whichever way it wants. The game has you crawling (craaaawling) around collecting hidden objects, only to find out, after 'beating' the boss, you must go back to collect all these amber blobs around the map. Since it takes forever to navigate through the levels of a screen it's a horrible experience. Walking slowly, trudging up and down the plants. Most of this game feels like filler. One of the puzzles is literally impossible to accomplish without a video (Reconstruct a Plant in Level 4). Some of the puzzles are interesting and well designed, others feel like unguided nonsense. Overall, this is a miss.Great visual design, bad game design.

Posted: April 22
												I enjoyed the art style and the music makes you feel like you're imersed in the natural setting or being a tiny bug. That being said some of the puzzles are annoyingly hard such as the one where you fix the flowers which by the end I had two left and was just clicking around hoping they would stick somewhere(looking nothing like the other pieces) and the Chinese Checkers like one where I swear I clicked and dragged diagonally with nothing happening and then *poof* it worked. Which brings me to the gameplay. Having to click and hold to move is a pain, especially when you're trying to make the character go a certain direction and he just seems to get stuck on nothing, or when trying to click on an object and he moves down or up to the next screen instead; I really feel this would do better with using the arrow keys or atleast WASD. There wasn't really much to the story other than bugs possessing each other which is weird to say the least. So in the end was it frustrating yes, I recommend having a walkthrough on hand, but if you like puzzles I'd say give it a try.
